$$
\left\|\pi U_{t} y\right\|_{H} \vee\left\|\pi U_{t} z\right\|_{H} \leq e^{\eta T} r
$$

Therefore, taking into account (4.20), (4.19) and (4.13), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|a(t, \omega, y)-a(t, \omega, z)\|_{H}^{2} & =e^{-2 \eta t}\left\|\alpha\left(t, \omega, \pi U_{t} y\right)-\alpha\left(t, \omega, \pi U_{t} z\right)\right\|_{H}^{2} \\
& \leq e^{-2 \eta t} \tilde{L}_{t}^{r}(\omega)\left\|\pi U_{t} y-\pi U_{t} z\right\|_{H}^{2} \leq \tilde{L}_{t}^{r}(\omega)\|y-z\|_{\mathcal{H}}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

showing that condition (4.5) is satisfied with $L^{r}$ replaced by $\tilde{L}^{r}$. Similarly, we can show that conditions (4.6) and (4.7) are satisfied with $L^{r}$ replaced by $\tilde{L}^{r}$. Now, let $(t, \omega, y) \in[0, T] \times \Omega \times \mathcal{H}$ be arbitrary. Taking into account (4.20), (4.19) and (4.16), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|a(t, \omega, y)\|_{\mathcal{H}}^{2} & =e^{-2 \eta t}\left\|\alpha\left(t, \omega, \pi U_{t} y\right)\right\|_{H}^{2} \leq e^{-2 \eta t} L_{t}(\omega)\left(1+\left\|\pi U_{t} y\right\|_{H}^{2}\right) \\
& \leq e^{-2 \eta t} L_{t}(\omega)\left(1+e^{2 \eta t}\|y\|_{\mathcal{H}}^{2}\right) \leq L_{t}(\omega)\left(1+\|y\|_{\mathcal{H}}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

showing that condition (4.8) is satisfied. In an analogous way we can show that conditions (4.9) and (4.10) are satisfied as well. The claim then follows directly by an application of Theorem 4.1.

Proposition 4.5. Suppose that, for every $\mathcal{F}_{0}$-measurable random variable $y_{0}: \Omega \rightarrow \mathcal{H}$, there exists a unique strong solution $Y$ to the $\operatorname{SDE}$ (4.4) with coefficients given as in (4.20)-(4.22) and with $Y_{0}=y_{0}$. Proof. Corollaries 3.9 and 3.11 from [50] also hold true in the present setup with an additional Poisson random measure, with identical proofs. Combining these two results completes the proof.

We close this section with an auxiliary result about the space of Hilbert-Schmidt operators, which will be useful later. For $k \in \mathbb{N}$, we denote by $H^{k}$ the $k$-fold cartesian product $H \times \ldots \times H$, which is a

separable Hilbert space when endowed with the norm

$$
\|h\|_{H^{k}}:=\left(\sum_{i=1}^{k}\left\|h^{i}\right\|_{H}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}, \quad h \in H^{k}
$$

Similarly, the space $H^{k \times d}$, endowed with the Frobenius norm

$$
\|h\|_{H^{k \times d}}:=\left(\sum_{i=1}^{k} \sum_{j=1}^{d}\left\|h^{i j}\right\|_{H}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}, \quad h \in H^{k \times d}
$$

is also a separable Hilbert space. Moreover, we recall that the space $L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}, H^{k}\right)$ of Hilbert-Schmidt operators, equipped with the Hilbert-Schmidt norm

$$
\|T\|_{L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}, H^{k}\right)}:=\left(\sum_{j=1}^{d}\left\|T e_{j}\right\|_{H^{k}}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}, \quad T \in L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}, H^{k}\right)
$$

is also a separable Hilbert space.
Lemma 4.6. $L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}, H^{k}\right) \cong H^{k \times d}$ (i.e., $L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}, H^{k}\right)$ and $H^{k \times d}$ are isometrically isomorphic).
Proof. For each $h \in H^{k \times d}$, we assign $T(h) \in L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}, H^{k}\right)$ as

$$
T(h) e_{j}:=\left(h^{i j}\right)_{i=1, \ldots, k}, \quad \text { for } j=1, \ldots, d
$$

which provides an isometric isomorphism $T: H^{k \times d} \rightarrow L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}, H^{k}\right)$.
4.2. Well-posedness of the real-world HJMM SPDE. In this section, we establish a general existence and uniqueness result for the SPDE arising in the HJM framework developed in Section 3, under the assumption that there exists an LMD (i.e., $\mathcal{D} \neq \emptyset$ ) and making use of Theorem 4.2.

We adopt the Musiela parametrization (see, e.g., [22]) for the instantaneous forward rates and write

$$
\eta_{t}^{i}(\xi):=f^{i}(t, t+\xi), \quad \text { for all }(t, \xi) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{2} \text { and } i \in I_{0}
$$

From now on, we assume that the set $I_{0}$ is finite and identify it by $\{0,1, \ldots, m\}$, for some $m \in \mathbb{N}$. The evolution of the $(m+1)$-dimensional family of forward curves is described by the process $\eta=$ $\left(\eta^{0}, \eta^{1}, \ldots, \eta^{m}\right)$, taking values in a suitable Hilbert space $H$ of functions $h: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{m+1}$ that will be specified below. According to this parameterization and assuming continuity of the map $T \mapsto f^{i}(t, T)$, for all $i=0,1, \ldots, m$, equation (3.2) can be written in vector form as follows:

$$
\eta_{t}(\xi)=S_{t} \eta_{0}(\xi)+\int_{0}^{t} S_{t-s} \alpha(s, s+\xi) \mathrm{d} s+\int_{0}^{t} S_{t-s} \beta(s, s+\xi) \mathrm{d} W_{s}+\int_{0}^{t} \int_{E} S_{t-s} \gamma(s, s+\xi, x) \tilde{\mu}(\mathrm{d} s, \mathrm{~d} x)
$$

for all $t \geq 0$, where $\left(S_{t}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ is the shift semigroup acting on the second time argument of $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$. As in Section 4.1, we work under the standing assumption that $\mu(\mathrm{d} t, \mathrm{~d} x)$ is a homogeneous Poisson random measure with compensator $\nu(\mathrm{d} t, \mathrm{~d} x)=F(\mathrm{~d} x) \mathrm{d} t$ and $E$ is a locally compact space.

We consider diffusive and jump volatilities $\beta$ and $\gamma$ with the following structure:

$$
\beta(t, t+\xi)=\beta\left(\eta_{t-}\right)(\xi) \quad \text { and } \quad \gamma(t, t+\xi, x)=\gamma\left(\eta_{t-}, x\right)(\xi)
$$

for all $(t, \xi) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{2}$ and $x \in E$, where the functions $\beta$ and $\gamma$ on the right-hand sides in (4.24) will satisfy the requirements of Assumption 4.10 below. For each $i=0,1, \ldots, m$, the $i$-th components $\beta^{i}\left(\eta_{t-}\right)(\xi)$ and $\gamma^{i}\left(\eta_{t-}, x\right)(\xi)$ are respectively a $d$-dimensional vector and a scalar, for all $t>0, \xi \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$and $x \in E$, and we write $\beta^{i, j}\left(\eta_{t-}\right)(\xi)$ for the $j$-th component of the vector $\beta^{i}\left(\eta_{t-}\right)(\xi)$, for $j=1, \ldots, d$.

Remark 4.7. The structure (4.24) allows for state-dependent volatilities, meaning that the volatility of each forward rate can depend on the whole family $\eta_{t-}=\left(\eta_{t-}^{0}, \eta_{t-}^{1}, \ldots, \eta_{t-}^{m}\right)$ of forward curves. It is possible to consider volatilities that depend on additional sources of randomness beyond the forward curves, in particular on the family $\left\{S_{t-}^{i} ; i \in I\right\}$ of spot processes. The results of this section can be extended to this more general setting with no changes in the proofs (see also Remark 4.8 below).

In this setting, an $H$-valued stochastic process $\eta$ satisfying (4.23) with volatilities as in (4.24) is a mild solution to the following Heath-Jarrow-Morton-Musiela (HJMM) SPDE:

$$
\mathrm{d} \eta_{t}=\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial \xi} \eta_{t}+\alpha\left(t, \eta_{t-}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} t+\beta\left(\eta_{t-}\right) \mathrm{d} W_{t}+\int_{E} \gamma\left(\eta_{t-}, x\right) \tilde{\mu}(\mathrm{d} t, \mathrm{~d} x)
$$

We refer to (4.25) as the real-world HJMM SPDE, since it is formulated under the real-world probability $\mathbb{P}$ (in contrast, standard formulations of the HJMM SPDE are under a risk-neutral probability $\mathbb{Q}$, see for instance [25]). By Theorem 3.4, the existence of LMDs (which in turn ensures market viability) corresponds to the existence of $\lambda \in L_{\mathrm{loc}}^{2}(W)$ and $\psi \in G_{\mathrm{loc}}(\mu)$ with $\psi>-1$ such that the drift term

$$
\alpha\left(t, \eta_{t-}\right)=\left(\alpha^{0}\left(t, \eta_{t-}\right), \alpha^{1}\left(t, \eta_{t-}\right), \ldots, \alpha^{m}\left(t, \eta_{t-}\right)\right)
$$

has the following structure (see Remark 3.6):

$$
\begin{aligned}
\alpha^{i}\left(t, \eta_{t-}\right)= & \beta^{i}\left(\eta_{t-}\right)^{\top} \bar{\beta}^{i}\left(\eta_{t-}\right)-\left(\lambda_{t}+b_{t}^{i}\right)^{\top} \beta^{i}\left(\eta_{t-}\right) \\
& +\int_{E} \gamma^{i}\left(\eta_{t-}, x\right)\left(1-e^{-\bar{\gamma}^{i}\left(\eta_{t-}, x\right)}\left(1+\psi_{t}(x)\right)\left(1+c_{t}^{i}(x)\right)\right) F(\mathrm{~d} x)
\end{aligned}
$$

for each $i=0,1, \ldots, m$, where we set $b^{0} \equiv 0$ and $c^{0} \equiv 0$ and make use of the notation

$$
\bar{\beta}^{i}\left(\eta_{t-}\right)(\cdot):=\int_{0} \beta^{i}\left(\eta_{t-}\right)(u) \mathrm{d} u \quad \text { and } \quad \bar{\gamma}^{i}\left(\eta_{t-}, x\right)(\cdot):=\int_{0} \gamma^{i}\left(\eta_{t-}, x\right)(u) \mathrm{d} u
$$

Remark 4.8. Observe that, for each $i=0,1, \ldots, m$, the drift term $\alpha^{i}\left(t, \eta_{t-}\right)$ depends on $\lambda_{t}$ and $\psi_{t}$ as well as on the processes $b_{t}^{i}$ and $c_{t}^{i}$ which are associated to the $i$-th spot process $S_{t}^{i}$. This implies that the drift term is not entirely determined by the forward curves $\eta_{t-}$, rather it depends on additional sources of randomness, unlike in the classical setting of the HJMM SPDE formulated under a riskneutral measure with a single term structure, as considered in [25]. This explains why, in the context of the real-world HJM framework of Section 3, we are naturally led to consider SPDEs with random locally Lipschitz coefficients (see Theorem 4.2), which are not covered by the existing theory.

To proceed, we need to define the space of functions on which we shall study the SPDE (4.25). To this effect, we fix an arbitrary constant $\rho>0$ and denote by $H_{\rho}^{k}$, for $k \in \mathbb{N}$, the space of all absolutely continuous functions $h: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{k}$ such that

$$
\|h\|_{\rho, k}:=\left(|h(0)|_{k}^{2}+\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}}\left|h^{\prime}(s)\right|_{k}^{2} e^{\rho s} \mathrm{~d} s\right)^{1 / 2}<+\infty
$$

where $|\cdot|_{k}$ denotes the Euclidean norm in $\mathbb{R}^{k}$. Moreover, we define

$$
H_{\rho}^{0, k}:=\left\{h \in H_{\rho}^{k}:|h(\infty)|_{k}=0\right\}
$$

The space $H_{\rho}^{k}$ has been already considered in [16, Section 4.1] and represents an extension to the multidimensional setting of the so-called Filipović space first introduced in [22] in the one-dimensional case. We collect in Appendix D several technical properties of the space $H_{\rho}=H_{\rho}^{1}$.

Remark 4.9. Note that the space $H_{\rho}^{k}$ corresponds to the $k$-fold cartesian product $H_{\rho} \times \ldots \times H_{\rho}$ and the norm defined in (4.27) can be expressed as $\|h\|_{\rho, k}=\left(\sum_{i=1}^{k}\left\|h^{i}\right\|_{\rho}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}$, for $h \in H_{\rho}^{k}$.

The main goal of this section is to establish existence and uniqueness of a mild solution to the real-world HJMM SPDE (4.25) with drift (4.26) on the space $H:=H_{\rho}^{m+1}$. We are interested in global solutions, i.e., $H$-valued stochastic processes that solve (4.25) on arbitrary time intervals.

We now introduce a set of assumptions which will ensure existence and uniqueness of a global mild solution to the HJMM SPDE (4.25). As in Appendix D, for each $\rho^{\prime}>\rho$ we introduce the constant

$$
K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}}:=\left(1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{\rho}}\right) \sqrt{\frac{1}{\rho^{\prime}\left(\rho^{\prime}-\rho\right)}}
$$

For any constant $K>0$, we denote by $W_{K}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$the inverse of the strictly increasing function

$$
V_{K}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}, \quad V_{K}(r):=r(1+r) \exp (K r)
$$

and we introduce the strictly increasing function

$$
w_{K}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}, \quad w_{K}(r):=W_{K}(r) \wedge r
$$

As usual, for $p \in(0,+\infty)$, we denote by $L^{p}(F)$ the space of all measurable functions $f: E \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that $\int_{E}|f(x)|^{p} F(\mathrm{~d} x)<+\infty$.

Assumption 4.10. There exist $\rho^{\prime}>\rho$, an optional locally bounded non-negative process $\Lambda$, a nonnegative function $\kappa \in L^{1}(F) \cap L^{2}(F) \cap L^{3}(F)$, a constant $M_{\beta} \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$and an increasing function $M_{\gamma}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$such that the following hold:
(i) the processes $\lambda: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $b: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{(m+1) \times d}$ are predictable and locally bounded.
(ii) the functions $\psi: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times E \rightarrow(-1,+\infty)$ and $c: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times E \rightarrow(-1,+\infty)^{m+1}$ are $\mathcal{P} \otimes \mathcal{B}(E)$ measurable and, for all $i=0,1, \ldots, m$, it holds that

$$
\left|\left(1+\psi_{t}(\omega, x)\right)\left(1+c_{t}^{i}(\omega, x)\right)\right| \leq \Lambda_{t}(\omega) \kappa(x), \quad \text { for all }(\omega, t, x) \in \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times E
$$

(iii) The function $\beta: H_{\rho}^{m+1} \rightarrow H_{\rho}^{(m+1) \times d}$ satisfies

$$
\begin{gathered}
\beta \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\operatorname{loc}}\left(H_{\rho}^{m+1}, H_{\rho}^{0,(m+1) \times d}\right) \\
\|\beta(h)\|_{\rho,(m+1) \times d} \leq M_{\beta} \sqrt{1+\|h\|_{\rho, m+1}}, \quad \text { for all } h \in H_{\rho}^{m+1}
\end{gathered}
$$

(iv) The function $\gamma: H_{\rho}^{m+1} \times E \rightarrow H_{\rho}^{m+1}$ is $\mathcal{B}\left(H_{\rho}^{m+1}\right) \otimes \mathcal{B}(E)$-measurable and satisfies

$$
\gamma(\cdot, x) \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\operatorname{loc}}\left(H_{\rho}^{m+1}, H_{\rho^{\prime}}^{0, m+1}\right), \quad \text { for all } x \in E
$$

Furthermore, for each $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$and $h, g \in H_{\rho}^{m+1}$ with $\|h\|_{\rho, m+1} \vee\|g\|_{\rho, m+1} \leq r$, it holds that

$$
\|\gamma(h, x)-\gamma(g, x)\|_{\rho^{\prime}, m+1} \leq \kappa(x) M_{\gamma}(r)\|h-g\|_{\rho, m+1}, \quad \text { for all } x \in E
$$

and

$$
\|\gamma(h, x)\|_{\rho^{\prime}, m+1} \leq w_{K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}}}\left(\kappa(x)\left(1+\|h\|_{\rho, m+1}\right)\right), \quad \text { for all }(h, x) \in H_{\rho}^{m+1} \times E
$$

Remark 4.11. Beyond the extension to a multi-dimensional setup, Assumption 4.10 significantly weakens the requirements of [25] by replacing global Lipschitz continuity and the boundedness condition imposed in [25, Assumption 3.1] with local Lipschitz continuity and a growth condition, respectively. Besides its mathematical interest, this generalization is essential in our framework in order to consider models that might not admit a risk-neutral probability. Indeed, translating the technical requirements of [25] onto the real-world probability would lead to restrictive conditions on the market prices of risk which would typically imply the true martingale property of an LMD and, hence, the existence of a risk-neutral probability, thus precluding models for which the latter fails to exist.

As shown in the following proposition, Assumption 4.10 suffices to ensure that the drift term (4.26) of SPDE (4.25) satisfies a linear growth condition and is locally Lipschitz. This represents a crucial step towards the applicability of the general existence and uniqueness result of Theorem 4.2 to the real-world HJMM SPDE (4.25).

Proposition 4.12. Suppose that Assumption 4.10 holds. Then the following holds:
(1) the function $\alpha$ takes values in $H_{\rho}^{0, m+1}$ and is $\mathcal{P} \otimes \mathcal{B}\left(H_{\rho}^{m+1}\right)$-measurable;
(2) for each $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$, there exist an optional locally bounded non-negative process $L^{r}$ and a constant $K(r) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$such that, for all $(\omega, t) \in \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+}$and $h, g \in H_{\rho}^{m+1}$ with $\|h\|_{\rho, m+1} \vee\|g\|_{\rho, m+1} \leq r$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\alpha(t, \omega, h)-\alpha(t, \omega, g)\|_{\rho, m+1}^{2} & \leq L_{t}^{r}(\omega)\|h-g\|_{\rho, m+1}^{2} \\
\|\beta(h)-\beta(g)\|_{L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}, H_{\rho}^{m+1}\right)}^{2} & \leq K(r)\|h-g\|_{\rho, m+1}^{2} \\
\int_{E}\|\gamma(h, x)-\gamma(g, x)\|_{\rho, m+1}^{2} F(\mathrm{~d} x) & \leq K(r)\|h-g\|_{\rho, m+1}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

(3) there exist an optional locally bounded non-negative process $L$ and a constant $K \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$such that, for all $(\omega, t, h) \in \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times H$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\alpha(t, \omega, h)\|_{\rho, m+1}^{2} & \leq L_{t}(\omega)\left(1+\|h\|_{\rho, m+1}^{2}\right) \\
\|\beta(h)\|_{L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}, H_{\rho}^{m+1}\right)}^{2} & \leq K\left(1+\|h\|_{\rho, m+1}^{2}\right) \\
\int_{E}\|\gamma(h, x)\|_{\rho, m+1}^{2} F(\mathrm{~d} x) & \leq K\left(1+\|h\|_{\rho, m+1}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. Taking into account Lemma 4.6 and Remark 4.9, the estimates (4.35) and (4.38) follow from (4.29) and (4.30), respectively. We structure the remaining part of the proof in a similar way to [25, Proposition 3.1]. Let $i \in\{0,1, \ldots, m\}$ and write

$$
\alpha^{i}(t, h)=\alpha_{1}^{i}(h)-\alpha_{2}^{i}(t, h)+\alpha_{3}^{i}(t, h)
$$

where, for all $(\omega, t, h) \in \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times H_{\rho}^{m+1}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\alpha_{1}^{i}(h) & :=\sum_{j=1}^{d} \beta^{i, j}(h) \bar{\beta}^{i, j}(h) \\
\alpha_{2}^{i}(t, \omega, h) & :=\sum_{j=1}^{d}\left(\lambda_{t}^{j}(\omega)+b_{t}^{i, j}(\omega)\right) \beta^{i, j}(h) \\
\alpha_{3}^{i}(t, \omega, h) & :=\int_{E} \gamma^{i}(h, x)\left(1-e^{-\bar{\gamma}^{i}(h, x)}\left(1+\psi_{t}(\omega, x)\right)\left(1+c_{t}^{i}(\omega, x)\right)\right) F(\mathrm{~d} x)
\end{aligned}
$$

Throughout the proof, for simplicity of notation we denote $\|h\|:=\|h\|_{\rho, 1}$, for $h \in H_{\rho}^{1}$. Taking into account (4.29) and (4.30) and making use of the notation introduced in Appendix D, Proposition D. 9 implies that

$$
\alpha_{1}^{i} \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\operatorname{loc}}\left(H_{\rho}^{m+1}, H_{\rho}^{0,1}\right) \cap \operatorname{LG}\left(H_{\rho}^{m+1}, H_{\rho}^{0,1}\right)
$$

Moreover, we have $\alpha_{2}^{i}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \Omega \times H_{\rho}^{m+1} \rightarrow H_{\rho}^{0,1}$ and $\alpha_{2}^{i}$ is $\mathcal{P} \otimes \mathcal{B}\left(H_{\rho}^{m+1}\right)$-measurable, because $\lambda^{j}$ and $b^{i, j}$ are predictable processes, for all $j=1, \ldots, d$. Using (4.29), there exists an increasing function $L: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$such that, for all $j=1, \ldots, d, r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$and $h, g \in H_{\rho}^{m+1}$ with $\|h\|_{\rho, m+1} \vee\|g\|_{\rho, m+1} \leq r$, we have

$$
\left\|\beta^{i, j}(h)-\beta^{i, j}(g)\right\| \leq L(r)\|h-g\|_{\rho, m+1}
$$

Let $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$be arbitrary. By Assumption 4.10, the non-negative process $L^{i, r}:=L(r) \sum_{j=1}^{d}\left|\lambda_{t}^{j}+b_{t}^{i, j}\right|$ is optional and locally bounded. For all $(\omega, t) \in \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+}$and $h, g \in H_{\rho}^{m+1}$ with $\|h\|_{\rho, m+1} \vee\|g\|_{\rho, m+1} \leq r$, we obtain

$$
\left\|\alpha_{2}^{i}(t, \omega, h)-\alpha_{2}^{i}(t, \omega, g)\right\| \leq L_{t}^{i, r}(\omega)\|h-g\|_{\rho, m+1}
$$

By (4.30) there exists a constant $N_{\beta} \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$such that, for all $j=1, \ldots, d$ and $h \in H_{\rho}$, it holds that

$$
\left\|\beta^{i, j}(h)\right\| \leq N_{\beta}\left(1+\|h\|_{\rho, m+1}\right)
$$

The non-negative process $L^{i}:=N_{\beta} \sum_{j=1}^{d}\left|\lambda_{t}^{j}+b_{t}^{i, j}\right|$ is optional and locally bounded. For all $(\omega, t, h) \in$ $\Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times H_{\rho}^{m+1}$, we obtain

$$
\left\|\alpha_{2}^{i}(t, \omega, h)\right\| \leq L_{t}^{i}(\omega)\left(1+\|h\|_{\rho, m+1}\right)
$$

Taking into account (4.28), (4.32) and (4.33), we can apply Proposition D. 11 with $(Z, \mathcal{Z})=\left(\mathbb{R}_{+} \times \Omega, \mathcal{P}\right)$. As a consequence, we have $\alpha_{3}^{i}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \Omega \times H_{\rho}^{m+1} \rightarrow H_{\rho}^{0,1}$ and $\alpha_{3}^{i}$ is $\mathcal{P} \otimes \mathcal{B}\left(H_{\rho}^{m+1}\right)$-measurable, because the functions $\psi$ and $c^{i}$ are $\mathcal{P} \otimes \mathcal{B}(E)$-measurable. Furthermore, there exists an increasing function $L_{1}^{i}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$such that, for all $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$and $h, g \in H_{\rho}^{m+1}$ with $\|h\|_{\rho, m+1} \vee\|g\|_{\rho, m+1} \leq r$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{E}\left\|\gamma^{i}(h, x)-\gamma^{i}(g, x)\right\|^{2} F(\mathrm{~d} x) & \leq L_{1}^{i}(r)\|h-g\|_{\rho, m+1}^{2} \\
\left\|\alpha_{3}^{i}(t, \omega, h)-\alpha_{3}^{i}(t, \omega, g)\right\| & \leq L_{1}^{i}(r)\left(1+\Lambda_{t}(\omega)\right)\|h-g\|_{\rho, m+1}, \quad \text { for all }(\omega, t) \in \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+}
\end{aligned}
$$

and there exists a constant $L_{2}^{i} \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$such that, for all $h \in H_{\rho}^{m+1}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{E}\left\|\gamma^{i}(h, x)\right\|^{2} F(\mathrm{~d} x) & \leq L_{2}^{i}\left(1+\|h\|_{\rho, m+1}^{2}\right) \\
\left\|\alpha_{3}^{i}(t, \omega, h)\right\| & \leq L_{2}^{i}\left(1+\Lambda_{t}(\omega)\right)\left(1+\|h\|_{\rho, m+1}\right), \quad \text { for all }(\omega, t) \in \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+}
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking into account Remark 4.9, the estimates (4.36) and (4.39) concerning $\gamma$ follow from (4.44) and (4.46). Furthermore, we obtain $\alpha: \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \Omega \times H_{\rho}^{m+1} \rightarrow H_{\rho}^{0, m+1}$ and $\alpha$ is $\mathcal{P} \otimes \mathcal{B}\left(H_{\rho}^{m+1}\right)$-measurable. The estimates (4.34) and (4.37) concerning $\alpha$ follow from (4.41), (4.42), (4.43), (4.45) and (4.47).

By relying on Assumption 4.10 and Proposition 4.12, we are in a position to prove the main result of this section, which establishes existence and uniqueness of the solution to the real-world HJMM SPDE (4.25) with drift (4.26). As noted in Remark 4.11, this result extends [25, Theorem 3.2], which, to the best of our knowledge, represents the most general available result on the well-posedness of the HJMM-SPDE. We recall that we are considering the state space $H=H_{\rho}^{m+1}$.

Theorem 4.13. Suppose that Assumption 4.10 holds. Then, for every initial family of curves $h_{0} \in H$, there exists a unique global mild solution $\left(\eta_{t}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ with càdlàg paths to (4.25) with $\eta_{0}=h_{0}$.

Proof. As a consequence of Theorem D. 1 and Remark 4.9, the space $\left(H,\|\cdot\|_{H}\right)$ is a separable Hilbert space and the shift semigroup $\left(S_{t}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ is a $C_{0}$-semigroup on $H$ with generator $A$ given by $A h=h^{\prime}$, for all $h \in D(A)$. Moreover, [5, Lemma 3.5] implies that the shift semigroup $\left(S_{t}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ is pseudo-contractive. By Proposition 4.12, conditions (4.13)-(4.18) are satisfied. The claim then follows by Theorem 4.2.
4.3. Monotonicity of term structures. In Section 3.3, we have derived abstract conditions ensuring the monotonicity of the term structures. In this section, we address the issue of monotonicity from an SPDE viewpoint, relating monotonicity to suitable invariance properties of the real-world SPDE (4.25). This approach has the advantage of providing sufficient conditions for monotonicity without requiring the martingale property of Definition 3.8. We work in the framework of Section 4.2, supposing in

particular that Assumption 4.10 holds. Consider the closed convex cone $K \subset H$ defined as

$$
K:=\left\{h=\left(h^{0}, h^{1}, \ldots, h^{m}\right) \in H: h^{1} \geq h^{2} \geq \ldots \geq h^{m}\right\}
$$

where we recall that the state space is given by $H=H_{\rho}^{m+1}$. We say that the closed convex cone $K$ is invariant for the SPDE (4.25) if, for each $h_{0} \in K$, we have $\eta \in K$ up to an evanescent set, where $\eta$ denotes the mild solution to the SPDE (4.25) with $\eta_{0}=h_{0}$. The invariance of closed convex cones for SPDEs has been investigated in a general setup in $[51,52]$ and in $[25]$ for the special case where $K$ is the cone of non-negative functions. The proof of the following theorem is analogous to that of [52, Corollary 8.6] and, therefore, omitted.

Theorem 4.14. Suppose that, for all $h \in K$,

$$
h+\gamma(h, x) \in K \quad F(\mathrm{~d} x)-\text { a.e. }
$$

and, for all $\xi \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$and $i, j=1, \ldots, m$ with $i<j$ such that $h^{i}(\xi)=h^{j}(\xi)$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \beta^{i}(h)(\xi)=\beta^{j}(h)(\xi) \\
& \alpha^{i}(t, \omega, h)(\xi)-\alpha^{j}(t, \omega, h)(\xi) \\
& \quad-\int_{E}\left(\gamma^{i}(h, x)(\xi)-\gamma^{j}(h, x)(\xi)\right) F(\mathrm{~d} x) \geq 0, \quad \text { outside of a set of }(\mathbb{P} \otimes \mathrm{d} t) \text {-measure zero. }
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, the closed convex cone $K$ is invariant for the SPDE (4.25).
Taking into account the specific structure of the drift $\alpha$ given by (4.26), we can now provide sufficient conditions for the invariance of the closed convex cone $K$ for the real-world HJMM SPDE (4.25).

Assumption 4.15. Condition (4.49) is satisfied. Furthermore, we assume that for all $h \in K, \xi \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$ and $i, j=1, \ldots, m$ with $i<j$ such that $h^{i}(\xi)=h^{j}(\xi)$, the following conditions are satisfied:

$$
\begin{aligned}

for $(\mathbb{P} \otimes \mathrm{d} t)$-a.e. $(\omega, t) \in \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+}$, which is equivalent to

4.4. Existence of affine realizations. The concept of finite-dimensional realizations allows reducing the inherently infinite-dimensional structure of HJM models to finite-dimensional factor models, which are more tractable for practical applications. The existence of finite-dimensional realizations has been the subject of substantial investigation in the context of one-dimensional HJM interest rate models under the risk-neutral setup (see, e.g., $[12,26]$ and also $[9]$ for an overview on the topic). For multicurve HJM interest rate models, conditions for the existence of finite-dimensional realizations have been recently obtained in [31] in the risk-neutral setup and assuming continuous paths. In this section, we extend these results by providing conditions for the existence of affine finite-dimensional realizations in the context of Lévy-driven HJM models for multiple term structures under the real-world probability.

We start by considering an SPDE of the following form on a separable Hilbert space $H$ :

$$
d X_{t}=\left(A X_{t}+\alpha\left(t, X_{t}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} t+\beta\left(t, X_{t-}\right) \mathrm{d} L_{t}, \quad X_{0}=x_{0}
$$

where $L$ is an $\mathbb{R}^{d}$-valued Lévy process, $A$ denotes the generator of a pseudo-contractive $C_{0}$-semigroup $\left(S_{t}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ on $H$ and $\alpha: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times H \rightarrow H$ and $\beta: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times H \rightarrow L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}, H\right)$. For each $j=1, \ldots, d$, we introduce the mapping $\beta^{j}: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times H \rightarrow H$ given by $\beta^{j}(\omega, t, h):=\beta(\omega, t, h) e_{j}$. We assume that

conditions (4.13), (4.14) and (4.16), (4.17) from Theorem 4.2 are satisfied, which ensures existence and uniqueness of mild solutions to the Lévy-driven SPDE (4.59).

Definition 4.18. Let $\phi=\left(\phi^{x_{0}}\right)_{x_{0} \in D(A)}$ be a family of $D(A)$-valued mappings $\phi^{x_{0}} \in C^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+} ; H\right)$ and $T \in L\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, V\right)$ an isomorphism, where $V \subset D(A)$ is an n-dimensional subspace, for some $n \in \mathbb{N}$. The SPDE (4.59) admits an $n$-dimensional affine realization induced by $(\phi, T)$ if, for every $x_{0} \in D(A)$, there exists an $\mathbb{R}^{n}$-valued càdlàg adapted process $Y^{x_{0}}$ such that the $D(A)$-valued process $X^{x_{0}}$ given by

$$
X_{t}^{x_{0}}:=\phi^{x_{0}}(t)+T Y_{t}^{x_{0}}, \quad \text { for all } t \in \mathbb{R}_{+}
$$

is a strong solution to the SPDE (4.59) with $X_{0}^{x_{0}}=x_{0}$.
The notion of affine realization is closely connected to invariant foliations (see, e.g., [48, 49], where the existence of affine realizations has been treated for one-dimensional HJM interest rate models under the risk-neutral setup). In this section, we do not pursue a systematic investigation of affine realizations in our general setup, rather we establish sufficient conditions which apply to the real-world HJMM SPDE (4.25) later on. We introduce the mapping $\nu: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times D(A) \rightarrow H$ as $\nu(\omega, t, h):=A h+\alpha(\omega, t, h)$.

Proposition 4.19. Let $\phi=\left(\phi^{x_{0}}\right)_{x_{0} \in D(A)}$ be a family of $D(A)$-valued mappings $\phi^{x_{0}} \in C^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+} ; H\right)$ with $\phi^{x_{0}}(0)=x_{0}$ such that $A \phi^{x_{0}}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow H$ is continuous for each $x_{0} \in D(A)$, and let $V \subset D(A)$ be an $n$-dimensional subspace. Suppose that, for all $x_{0} \in D(A),(\omega, t) \in \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+}$and $v \in V$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \nu\left(\omega, t, \phi^{x_{0}}(t)+v\right) \in \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t} \phi^{x_{0}}(t)+V \\
& \beta^{j}\left(\omega, t, \phi^{x_{0}}(t)+v\right) \in V, \quad \text { for all } j=1, \ldots, d
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, for every isomorphism $T \in L\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, V\right)$, the SPDE (4.59) admits an n-dimensional affine realization induced by $(\phi, T)$.

Proof. Let $T \in L\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, V\right)$ be an arbitrary isomorphism and $x_{0} \in D(A)$. By (4.61) and (4.62), there exist mappings $\mu^{x_{0}}: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{n}$ and $\gamma^{x_{0}}: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}, \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ such that, for all $(\omega, t, y) \in \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R}^{n}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nu\left(\omega, t, \phi^{x_{0}}(t)+T y\right) & =\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t} \phi^{x_{0}}(t)+T \mu^{x_{0}}(\omega, t, y) \\
\beta^{j}\left(\omega, t, \phi^{x_{0}}(t)+T y\right) & =T \gamma^{x_{0}, j}(\omega, t, y), \quad \text { for all } j=1, \ldots, d
\end{aligned}
$$

Noting that $A \phi^{x_{0}}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow H$ is continuous, from (4.63) and (4.64) we deduce that $\mu^{x_{0}}$ and $\gamma^{x_{0}}$ satisfy the local Lipschitz conditions (4.5), (4.6) and the linear growth conditions (4.8), (4.9). Hence, by Theorem 4.1 there exists a unique strong solution $Y^{x_{0}}$ to the $\mathbb{R}^{n}$-valued SDE

$$
d Y_{t}^{x_{0}}=\mu^{x_{0}}\left(t, Y_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\gamma^{x_{0}}\left(t, Y_{t-}\right) \mathrm{d} L_{t}, \quad Y_{0}^{x_{0}}=0
$$

Let us now define the $D(A)$-valued process $X^{x_{0}}$ by (4.60). In view of (4.63) and (4.64), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
X_{t}^{x_{0}} & =\phi^{x_{0}}(t)+T Y_{t}^{x_{0}} \\
& =\phi^{x_{0}}(0)+\int_{0}^{t} \frac{\mathrm{~d}}{\mathrm{~d} s} \phi^{x_{0}}(s) \mathrm{d} s+\int_{0}^{t} T \mu^{x_{0}}\left(s, Y_{s}^{x_{0}}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\int_{0}^{t} T \gamma^{x_{0}}\left(s, Y_{s-}^{x_{0}}\right) \mathrm{d} L_{s} \\
& =x_{0}+\int_{0}^{t} \nu\left(s, X_{s}^{x_{0}}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\int_{0}^{t} \beta\left(s, X_{s}^{x_{0}}\right) \mathrm{d} L_{s}, \quad \text { a.s. for all } t \in \mathbb{R}_{+}
\end{aligned}
$$

thus proving that $X^{x_{0}}$ is a strong solution to the SPDE (4.59) with $X_{0}^{x_{0}}=x_{0}$.
We point out that the proof of Proposition 4.19 is constructive in the sense that the state processes $Y^{x_{0}}$, for each $x_{0} \in D(A)$, is given by the solution to the $\mathbb{R}^{n}$-valued SDE (4.65).

Proposition 4.20. Let $V \subset D(A)$ be an $n$-dimensional $A$-invariant subspace such that the following conditions are fulfilled:
(1) for all $(\omega, t, h) \in \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times H$, we have

$$
\beta^{j}(\omega, t, h) \in V, \quad \text { for all } j=1, \ldots, d
$$

(2) there exists a $D(A)$-valued mapping $\alpha_{1} \in C^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+} ; H\right)$ such that $A \alpha_{1}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow H$ is continuous and a mapping $\alpha_{2}: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times H \rightarrow V$ such that

$$
\alpha(\omega, t, h)=\alpha_{1}(t)+\alpha_{2}(\omega, t, h), \quad \text { for all }(\omega, t, h) \in \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times H
$$

Define the family $\phi=\left(\phi^{x_{0}}\right)_{x_{0} \in D(A)}$ by

$$
\phi^{x_{0}}(t):=S_{t} x_{0}+\int_{0}^{t} S_{t-s} \alpha_{1}(s) \mathrm{d} s, \quad \text { for all } t \in \mathbb{R}_{+}
$$

Then, for every isomorphism $T \in L\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, V\right)$, the SPDE (4.59) has an n-dimensional affine realization induced by $(\phi, T)$.

Proof. For $x_{0} \in D(A)$, the mapping $\phi^{x_{0}}$ is a solution to the inhomogeneous initial value problem

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t} \phi(t)=A \phi(t)+\alpha_{1}(t), \quad \phi(0)=x_{0}
$$

see for instance [45, Theorem 4.2.4]. In particular, it follows that $A \phi^{x_{0}}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow H$ is continuous. Condition (4.62) is satisfied due to (4.66). Furthermore, for all $(\omega, t) \in \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+}$and $v \in V$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nu\left(\omega, t, \phi^{x_{0}}(t)+v\right) & =A \phi^{x_{0}}(t)+A v+\alpha_{1}(t)+\alpha_{2}\left(\omega, t, \phi^{x_{0}}(t)+v\right) \\
& =\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t} \phi^{x_{0}}(t)+A v+\alpha_{2}\left(\omega, t, \phi^{x_{0}}(t)+v\right) \in \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t} \phi^{x_{0}}(t)+V
\end{aligned}
$$

where in the last step we have used that $V$ is $A$-invariant. This shows that condition (4.61) holds. The claim then follows by applying Proposition 4.19.

Proposition 4.21. Suppose that the SPDE (4.59) has an n-dimensional affine realization induced by $(\phi, T)$. Let $\ell \in L\left(H, \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ be such that the linear operator $S:=\ell T \in L\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ is an isomorphism and let $R \in L\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, V\right)$ be the isomorphism given by $R:=T S^{-1}$. Then, for each $x_{0} \in D(A)$, the following hold:
(1) the strong solution $X^{x_{0}}$ to the $\operatorname{SPDE}$ (4.59) with $X_{0}^{x_{0}}=x_{0}$ satisfies

$$
X_{t}^{x_{0}}=\varphi^{x_{0}}(t)+R Z_{t}^{x_{0}}, \quad \text { for all } t \in \mathbb{R}_{+}
$$

where $Z^{x_{0}}:=\ell\left(X^{x_{0}}\right)$, and the mapping $\varphi^{x_{0}}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow H$ is given by

$$
\varphi^{x_{0}}(t)=(\mathrm{Id}-R \ell) \phi^{x_{0}}(t), \quad \text { for all } t \in \mathbb{R}_{+}
$$

(2) the process $Z^{x_{0}}$ is the strong solution to the $\mathbb{R}^{n}$-valued $S D E$

$$
d Z_{t}^{x_{0}}=\bar{\mu}^{x_{0}}\left(t, Z_{t}^{x_{0}}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\bar{\gamma}^{x_{0}}\left(t, Z_{t-}^{x_{0}}\right) \mathrm{d} L_{t}, \quad Z_{0}^{x_{0}}=\ell\left(x_{0}\right)
$$

where $\bar{\mu}^{x_{0}}: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{n}$ and $\bar{\gamma}^{x_{0}}: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}, \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ are given by

$$
\begin{gathered}
\bar{\mu}^{x_{0}}(\omega, t, z)=\ell \nu\left(\omega, t, \varphi^{x_{0}}(t)+R z\right) \\
\bar{\gamma}^{x_{0}}(\omega, t, z)=\ell \beta\left(\omega, t, \varphi^{x_{0}}(t)+R z\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Proof. Applying the operator $\ell$ to equation (4.60) we see that

$$
Y_{t}^{x_{0}}=S^{-1} \ell\left(X_{t}^{x_{0}}-\phi^{x_{0}}(t)\right), \quad \text { for all } t \in \mathbb{R}_{+}
$$

Inserting this expression for $Y^{x_{0}}$ into (4.60) we arrive at (4.68). Furthermore, we have

$$
\ell\left(X_{t}^{x_{0}}\right)=\ell\left(x_{0}\right)+\int_{0}^{t} \ell \nu\left(s, X_{s}^{x_{0}}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\int_{0}^{t} \ell \beta\left(s, X_{s-}^{x_{0}}\right) \mathrm{d} L_{s}, \quad \text { for all } t \in \mathbb{R}_{+}
$$

Together with (4.68), this completes the proof.
After these preparations, we are now in a position to study the existence of affine realizations for the real-world HJMM SPDE (4.25) on the state space $H:=H_{\rho}^{m+1}$, for some $\rho>0$. For simplicity, we first assume that the SPDE (4.25) is driven by a one-dimensional Brownian motion $W$. Furthermore, we assume that the volatility $\beta$ is constant and given by

$$
\beta=\left(c_{i} e^{\delta_{i}}\right)_{i=0,1, \ldots, m}
$$

with constants $c_{i} \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\delta_{i}<-\rho / 2$ for $i=0,1, \ldots, m$. In view of (4.26), the drift $\alpha$ is then given by

$$
\alpha^{i}(\omega, t, h)=\beta^{i} \bar{\beta}^{i}-\left(\lambda_{t}(\omega)+b_{t}^{i}(\omega)\right) \beta^{i}, \quad \text { for } i=0,1, \ldots, m
$$

where $b^{0} \equiv 0$. We define the $(m+1)$-dimensional $D(\mathrm{~d} / \mathrm{d} \xi)$-invariant subspace $V \subset D(\mathrm{~d} / \mathrm{d} \xi)$ as

$$
V:=\left\{\left(v^{i} e^{\delta_{i}}\right)_{i=0,1, \ldots, m}: v=\left(v^{0}, v^{1}, \ldots, v^{m}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{m+1}\right\}
$$

The drift $\alpha$ admits then a decomposition of the form (4.67) with

$$
\alpha_{1}=\left(\beta^{i} \bar{\beta}^{i}\right)_{i=0,1, \ldots, m} \quad \text { and } \quad \alpha_{2}(t, \omega)=\left(-\left(\lambda_{t}(\omega)+b_{t}^{i}(\omega)\right) \beta^{i}\right)_{i=0,1, \ldots, m}
$$

In view of Proposition 4.20, the real-world HJMM SPDE (4.25) admits an $(m+1)$-dimensional affine realization. We are especially interested in constructing a realization where the state process is given by the short end of the forward curves, in analogy to the concept of short-rate realization in the context of interest rate models (see, e.g., [12]). For this purpose, let $\ell \in L\left(H, \mathbb{R}^{m+1}\right)$ be given by

$$
\ell(h)=\left(h^{0}(0), \ldots, h^{m}(0)\right), \quad \text { for } h \in H
$$

Proposition 4.22. For each $h_{0} \in D(\mathrm{~d} / \mathrm{d} \xi)$, the following hold:
(1) the strong solution $\eta^{h_{0}}$ to the real-world HJMM SPDE (4.25) with $\eta_{0}^{h_{0}}=h_{0}$ satisfies

$$
\eta_{t}^{h_{0}}=\varphi^{h_{0}}(t)+\left(Z_{t}^{h_{0}, i} e^{\delta_{i}}\right)_{i=0,1, \ldots, m}, \quad \text { for all } t \in \mathbb{R}_{+}
$$

where $Z^{h_{0}}:=\ell\left(\eta^{h_{0}}\right)$ and the mapping $\varphi^{h_{0}}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow H$ has components

$$
\varphi^{h_{0}, i}(t):=S_{t} h_{0}^{i}-h_{0}^{i}(t) e^{\delta_{i^{\prime}}}+\frac{c_{t}^{2}}{2 \delta_{i}^{2}}\left(e^{2 \delta_{i} t}-1\right)\left(e^{\delta_{i^{\prime}}}-1\right) e^{\delta_{i^{\prime}}}, \text { for all } t \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \text {and } i=0,1, \ldots, m
$$

(2) the state process $Z^{h_{0}}$ is the strong solution to the $\mathbb{R}^{m+1}$-valued $S D E$

$$
d Z_{t}^{h_{0}}=\bar{\mu}^{h_{0}}\left(t, Z_{t}^{h_{0}}\right) \mathrm{d} t+c \mathrm{~d} W_{t}, \quad Z_{0}^{h_{0}}=\ell\left(h_{0}\right)
$$

where $c:=\left(c_{0}, c_{1}, \ldots, c_{m}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{m+1}$ and the coefficient $\bar{\mu}^{h_{0}}: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R}^{m+1} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{m+1}$ has components

$$
\bar{\mu}^{h_{0}, i}(\omega, t, z):=-c_{i}\left(\lambda_{t}(\omega)+b_{t}^{i}(\omega)\right)+\kappa^{h_{0}, i}(t)+\delta_{i} z^{i}, \quad \text { for all } i=0,1, \ldots, m
$$

where, for each $i=0,1, \ldots, m$, the mapping $\kappa^{h_{0}, i}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is given by

$$
\kappa^{h_{0}, i}(t)=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t} h_{0}^{i}(t)-\delta_{i} h_{0}^{i}(t)+\frac{c_{t}^{2}}{2 \delta_{i}}\left(e^{2 \delta_{i} t}-1\right), \quad \text { for all } t \in \mathbb{R}_{+}
$$

Proof. Let $T \in L\left(\mathbb{R}^{m+1}, V\right)$ be the linear isomorphism given by

$$
T y:=\left(y^{i} e^{\delta_{i}}\right)_{i=0,1, \ldots, m}
$$

Using Proposition 4.20, the real-world HJMM SPDE (4.25) has an $(m+1)$-dimensional affine realization induced by $(\phi, T)$, where the family $\phi=\left(\phi^{h_{0}}\right)_{h_{0} \in D(\mathrm{~d} / \mathrm{d} \xi)}$ is given by

$$
\phi^{h_{0}}(t)=S_{t} h_{0}+\int_{0}^{t} S_{t-s} \alpha_{1} \mathrm{~d} s, \quad \text { for all } t \in \mathbb{R}_{+}
$$

Note that $S:=\ell T \in L\left(\mathbb{R}^{m+1}\right)$ is simply given by $S=\mathrm{Id}$. The isomorphism $R:=T S^{-1} \in L\left(\mathbb{R}^{m+1}, V\right)$ then reduces to $R=T$ and, therefore, $R \ell \in L(H, V)$ is given by

$$
R \ell h=\left(h^{i}(0) e^{\delta_{i}}\right)_{i=0,1, \ldots, m}, \quad \text { for } h \in H
$$

A straightforward calculation shows that

$$
\int_{0}^{t} S_{t-s} \alpha_{1} \mathrm{~d} s=\left(\frac{c_{i}^{2}}{2 \delta_{i}^{2}}\left(\left(e^{2 \delta_{i} t}-1\right) e^{\delta_{i^{\prime}}}-2\left(e^{\delta_{i} t}-1\right)\right) e^{\delta_{i^{\prime}}}\right)_{i=0,1, \ldots, m}
$$

Therefore, we have that

$$
R \ell \int_{0}^{t} S_{t-s} \alpha_{1} \mathrm{~d} s=\left(\frac{c_{i}^{2}}{2 \delta_{i}^{2}}\left(e^{2 \delta_{i} t}-2 e^{\delta_{i} t}+1\right) e^{\delta_{i^{\prime}}}\right)_{i=0,1, \ldots, m}
$$

In turn, this implies that the mapping $\varphi^{h_{0}}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow H$ defined according to (4.69) is given by (4.75). Furthermore, the mapping $\bar{\gamma}^{h_{0}}: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R}^{m+1} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{m+1}$ defined according to (4.72) is given by

$$
\bar{\gamma}^{h_{0}}(\omega, t, z)=\ell \beta\left(\omega, t, \varphi^{h_{0}}(t)+R z\right)=\ell\left(c_{i} e^{\delta_{i}}\right)_{i=0,1, \ldots, m}=c
$$

and the mapping $\bar{\mu}^{h_{0}}: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R}^{m+1} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{m+1}$ defined according to (4.71) is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\mu}^{h_{0}}(\omega, t, z) & =\ell \nu\left(\omega, t, \varphi^{h_{0}}(t)+R z\right)=\ell \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} \xi}\left(\varphi^{h_{0}}(t)+R z\right)+\ell \alpha_{2}\left(\omega, t, \varphi^{h_{0}}(t)+R z\right) \\
& =\ell \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} \xi} \varphi^{h_{0}}(t)+\left(\delta_{i} z^{i}\right)_{i=0,1, \ldots, m}+\left(-c_{i}\left(\lambda_{t}(\omega)+b_{t}^{i}(\omega)\right)\right)_{i=0,1, \ldots, m}
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking into account (4.75), we have

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} \xi} \varphi^{h_{0}}(t)=\left(S_{t} \frac{\mathrm{~d}}{\mathrm{~d} \xi} h_{0}^{i}-\delta_{i} h_{0}^{i}(t) e^{\delta_{i^{\prime}}}+\frac{c_{i}^{2}}{2 \delta_{i}}\left(e^{2 \delta_{i} t}-1\right)\left(2 e^{2 \delta_{i^{\prime}}}-e^{\delta_{i^{\prime}}}\right)\right)_{i=0,1, \ldots, m}
$$

and, therefore,

$$
\ell \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} \xi} \varphi^{h_{0}}(t)=\left(\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t} h_{0}^{i}(t)-\delta_{i} h_{0}^{i}(t)+\frac{c_{i}^{2}}{2 \delta_{i}}\left(e^{2 \delta_{i} t}-1\right)\right)_{i=0,1, \ldots, m}
$$

At this stage, the result follows by an application of Proposition 4.21.
Remark 4.23. In the particular case $m=0$ and $\lambda \equiv 0$, the real-world HJMM SPDE (4.25) reduces to the Hull-White extension of the Vasiček model under a risk-neutral probability. In this case, it is straightforward to check that the result of Proposition 4.22 coincides with the result obtained when performing the inversion of the yield curve (see, for instance, [23, Section 5.4.5]).

Proposition 4.20 can also be applied to the real-world HJMM SPDE (4.25) driven by a general Lévy process. However, the results of [47] indicate that some restrictions will arise on the functions $\psi$ and $c$, already in the one-dimensional case. For simplicity, let $L$ be a one-dimensional Lévy process of the form $L=W+x *\left(\mu^{L}-\nu\right)$, where $W$ is a Brownian motion and $\nu(\mathrm{d} t, \mathrm{~d} x)=F(\mathrm{~d} x) \mathrm{d} t$ is the compensator of $\mu^{L}$ with Lévy measure $F$. Similarly as above, we assume that the volatility $\beta$ is constant and given by (4.73). Furthermore, we assume that $\psi$ and $c$ are deterministic. In view of (4.26), the drift term $\alpha$ is then given by

$$
\alpha^{i}(\omega, t, h)=\beta^{i} \bar{\beta}^{i}-\left(\lambda_{t}(\omega)+b_{t}^{i}(\omega)\right) \beta^{i}+\beta^{i} \int_{\mathbb{R}} x\left(1-e^{-x \bar{\beta}^{i}}\left(1+\psi_{t}(x)\right)\left(1+c_{t}^{i}(x)\right)\right) F(\mathrm{~d} x)
$$

for all $i=0,1, \ldots, m$, where $b^{0} \equiv 0$ and $c^{0} \equiv 0$. Let $V \subset D(\mathrm{~d} / \mathrm{d} \xi)$ be the $(m+1)$-dimensional $D(\mathrm{~d} / \mathrm{d} \xi)$-invariant subspace given by (4.74). Since $\psi$ and $c$ are deterministic, the drift $\alpha$ admits a decomposition of the form (4.67) with

$$
\begin{aligned}
\alpha_{1}(t) & =\left(\beta^{i} \bar{\beta}^{i}+\beta^{i} \int_{\mathbb{R}} x\left(1-e^{-x \bar{\beta}^{i}}\left(1+\psi_{t}(x)\right)\left(1+c_{t}(x)\right)\right) F(\mathrm{~d} x)\right)_{i=0,1, \ldots, m} \\
\alpha_{2}(\omega, t) & =\left(-\left(\lambda_{t}(\omega)+b_{t}^{i}(\omega)\right) \beta^{i}\right)_{i=0,1, \ldots, m}
\end{aligned}
$$

In view of Proposition 4.20, we can conclude that the real-world HJMM SPDE (4.25) admits an $(m+1)$ dimensional affine realization, provided that $\alpha_{1}$ is a $D(\mathrm{~d} / \mathrm{d} \xi)$-valued mapping of class $C^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+} ; H\right)$ such that $\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} \xi} \alpha_{1}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow H$ is continuous.

# Appendix A. Proof of Theorem 2.5 

Proof. For each $n \in \mathbb{N}$, let us denote by $\mathcal{X}_{1,[0, n]}:=\left\{X_{\wedge n}: X \in \mathcal{X}_{1}\right\}$ the set of all elements of $\mathcal{X}_{1}$ stopped at $n$. The set $1+\mathcal{X}_{1,[0, n]}$ satisfies the requirements of [40, Definition 1.1], since fork-convexity follows as a consequence of [18, Lemma 2.1] (see also [19, proof of Theorem 4.7]), and is closed in the semimartingale topology by definition. Suppose first that NUPBR holds. Then, for every $n \in \mathbb{N}$, the set $\mathcal{X}_{1}(n)$ is bounded in probability and therefore, by [40, Theorem 1.7], there exists an element $\widehat{X}^{n} \in \mathcal{X}_{1,[0, n]}$ with $\widehat{X}^{n}>-1$ such that $(1+X) /\left(1+\widehat{X}^{n}\right)$ is a supermartingale, for every $X \in \mathcal{X}_{1,[0, n]}$. For each $n \in \mathbb{N}$, let us denote $Z^{n}:=1 /\left(1+\widehat{X}^{n}\right)$. Similarly as in the proof of [14, Proposition 1], we show that the elements $Z^{n}, n \in \mathbb{N}$, can be concatenated into a supermartingale deflator. For all $t \geq 0$, let $n(t):=\min \{n \in \mathbb{N}: n>t\}$ and define the càdlàg process

$$
Z_{t}:=\prod_{k=1}^{n(t)} \frac{Z_{k \wedge t}^{k}}{Z_{(k-1) \wedge t}^{k}}, \quad \text { for all } t \geq 0
$$

Notice that this definition implies that, if $t \in(m-1, m]$ for some $m \in \mathbb{N}$, then $Z_{t}=\prod_{k=1}^{m}\left(Z_{k \wedge t}^{k} / Z_{k-1}^{k}\right)$. Let $X \in \mathcal{X}_{1}$ and $s<t$. Suppose first that $t \in(s, n(s)] \subseteq(n(s)-1, n(s)]$. In this case, we can compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[Z_{t}\left(1+X_{t}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{s}\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[\prod_{k=1}^{n(s)} \frac{Z_{k \wedge t}^{k}}{Z_{k-1}^{k}}\left(1+X_{t}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{s}\right] \\
& =\prod_{k=1}^{n(s)-1} \frac{Z_{k}^{k}}{Z_{k-1}^{k}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left.\frac{Z_{t}^{n(s)}}{Z_{n(s)-1}^{n(s)}}\left(1+X_{t}\right) \right\rvert\, \mathcal{F}_{s}\right] \\
& \leq \prod_{k=1}^{n(s)-1} \frac{Z_{k}^{k}}{Z_{k-1}^{k}} \frac{Z_{s}^{n(s)}\left(1+X_{s}\right)}{Z_{n(s)-1}^{n(s)}}=\prod_{k=1}^{n(s)} \frac{Z_{k \wedge s}^{k}}{Z_{k-1}^{k}}\left(1+X_{s}\right)=Z_{s}\left(1+X_{s}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the inequality follows from the fact that $Z^{n(s)}(1+X)$ is a supermartingale on $[0, n(s)]$. This shows that the supermartingale property holds for $t \in(s, n(s)]$. Proceeding by induction, to prove that $Z$ is a supermartingale deflator it suffices to show that, if the supermartingale property holds for $t \in(s, n(s)+l]$, for some $l \in \mathbb{N}$, then it also holds for $t \in(n(s)+l, n(s)+l+1]$. To this effect, we compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[Z_{t}\left(1+X_{t}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{s}\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[Z_{t}\left(1+X_{t}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{n(s)+l}\right] \mid \mathcal{F}_{s}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\left.Z_{n(s)+l} \mathbb{E}\left[\left.\frac{Z_{t}^{n(s)+l+1}}{Z_{n(s)+l}^{n(s)+l+1}}\left(1+X_{t}\right) \right\rvert\, \mathcal{F}_{n(s)+l}\right] \right\rvert\, \mathcal{F}_{s}\right] \\
& \leq \mathbb{E}\left[Z_{n(s)+l}\left(1+X_{n(s)+l}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{s}\right] \leq Z_{s}\left(1+X_{s}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the first inequality follows from the supermartingale property of $Z^{n(s)+l+1}(1+X)$ on the interval $[0, n(s)+l+1]$ and the second inequality from the induction step. Since $Z_{0}=1$, this completes the proof that the process $Z$ defined in (A.1) is a supermartingale deflator in the sense of Definition 2.4. We now prove that $1 / Z \in 1+\mathcal{X}_{1}$. To this effect, note that

$$
\widehat{X}_{t}:=\frac{1}{Z_{t}}-1=\prod_{k=1}^{n(t)} \frac{1+\widehat{X}_{k \wedge t}^{k}}{1+\widehat{X}_{(k-1) \wedge t}^{k}}-1, \quad \text { for all } t \geq 0
$$

Since $\widehat{X}_{\wedge 1}=\widehat{X}^{1} \in \mathcal{X}_{1,[0,1]}$ and $\mathcal{X}_{1,[0, n]} \subseteq \mathcal{X}_{1}$, for every $n \in \mathbb{N}$, we have that $\widehat{X}_{\wedge 1} \in \mathcal{X}_{1}$. Proceeding by induction, suppose that $\widehat{X}_{\wedge n} \in \mathcal{X}_{1}$, for some $n \in \mathbb{N}$. Then, the definition of $\widehat{X}$ implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
1+\widehat{X}_{t \wedge(n+1)} & =\mathbf{1}_{\{t<n\}}\left(1+\widehat{X}_{t \wedge n}\right)+\mathbf{1}_{\{t \geq n\}} \prod_{k=1}^{n(t)} \frac{1+\widehat{X}_{k \wedge t \wedge(n+1)}^{k}}{1+\widehat{X}_{(k-1) \wedge t \wedge(n+1)}^{k}} \\
& =\mathbf{1}_{\{t<n\}}\left(1+\widehat{X}_{t \wedge n}\right)+\mathbf{1}_{\{t \geq n\}} \frac{1+\widehat{X}_{n}}{1+\widehat{X}_{n}^{n+1}}\left(1+\widehat{X}_{t}^{n+1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\widehat{X}^{n+1} \in \mathcal{X}_{1,[0, n+1]} \subseteq \mathcal{X}_{1}$ and the set $\mathcal{X}_{1}$ is fork-convex, it follows that $\widehat{X}_{\wedge(n+1)} \in \mathcal{X}_{1}$. We have thus shown that $\widehat{X}_{\wedge n} \in \mathcal{X}_{1}$, for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$. Since $\widehat{X}$ is a semimartingale and $\widehat{X}_{\wedge n}=\mathbf{1}_{[0, n]} \cdot \widehat{X}$, for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$, the closedness of $\mathcal{X}_{1}$ in the semimartingale topology implies that $\widehat{X} \in \mathcal{X}_{1}$.

Conversely, if a process $Z$ is a supermartingale deflator and $X \in \mathcal{X}_{1}$, then the supermartingale property of $Z(1+X)$ together with the fact that $Z_{0} \leq 1$ implies that $\mathbb{E}\left[Z_{T}\left(1+X_{T}\right)\right] \leq 1$, for every $T \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$. This implies that the set $Z_{T} \mathcal{X}_{1}(T)$ is bounded in probability and, hence, NUPBR holds.

Finally, suppose that $Z$ is a local martingale deflator and let $n \in \mathbb{N}$ and $A \in \mathcal{A}^{n}$. By definition, $Z X^{A}$ is an $\mathbb{R}^{n}$-valued local martingale. For every $H \in L\left(X^{A}\right)$ with $X:=H \cdot X^{A} \geq-1$, the process $Z X$ is a local martingale (see, e.g., [28, Lemma 4.2]). Since every non-negative local martingale with integrable initial value is a supermartingale, this implies that $Z(1+X)$ is a supermartingale, meaning that $Z$ is a supermartingale deflator for the set $\cup_{n \geq 1} \mathcal{X}_{1}^{n}$. By Fatou's lemma, the same property holds for the closure $\mathcal{X}_{1}$ in the semimartingale topology, thus proving that $Z$ is a supermartingale deflator.

# Appendix B. Conditional expectation with respect to a Doléans measure 

We recall the notion of conditional expectation with respect to a Doléans measure, as introduced in [34] (see also [35, Section III.3c]). Let $\mu$ be an integer-valued random measure on $\mathbb{R}_{+} \times E$ with compensator $\nu$. The positive Doléans measure $M_{\mu}$ on $\left(\Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times E, \mathcal{F} \otimes \mathcal{B}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right) \otimes \mathcal{B}(E)\right)$ is defined by

$$
M_{\mu}[\varphi]:=\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{E} \varphi_{t}(x) \mu(\mathrm{d} t, \mathrm{~d} x)\right], \quad \text { for all measurable functions } \varphi: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times E \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}
$$

We denote by $M_{\mu}[\varphi \mid \widetilde{\mathcal{P}}]$ the conditional expectation relative to $M_{\mu}$ of a measurable function $\varphi$ with respect to the sigma-field $\widetilde{\mathcal{P}}:=\mathcal{P} \otimes \mathcal{B}(E)$. The conditional expectation is well-defined for every nonnegative measurable function $\varphi$ and can be extended to real-valued measurable functions $\varphi$ as long as the measure $\left|\varphi_{t}(\omega, x)\right| \mu(\omega ; \mathrm{d} t, \mathrm{~d} x)$ is $\widetilde{\mathcal{P}}-\sigma$-finite, which in particular holds if the process $|\varphi| * \mu$ is locally integrable. By definition, $M_{\mu}[\varphi \mid \widetilde{\mathcal{P}}]$ is the $M_{\mu}$-a.e. unique $\widetilde{\mathcal{P}}$-measurable function $U$ such that

$$
M_{\mu}[\varphi V]=M_{\mu}[U V], \quad \text { for all } \widetilde{\mathcal{P}} \text {-measurable bounded functions } V
$$

In the proof of Theorem 3.4 we make use of the following lemma, which can be deduced from [34]. We provide a self-contained proof which relies only on standard notions found in [35].

Lemma B.1. Let $\varphi: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times E \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a measurable function. The increasing process $|\varphi| * \mu$ is locally integrable if and only if $M_{\mu}[|\varphi| \widetilde{\mathcal{P}}] * \nu$ is locally integrable. In this case, the compensator of the finite variation process $\varphi * \mu$ is given by $M_{\mu}[\varphi \mid \widetilde{\mathcal{P}}] * \nu$.

Proof. Suppose there exists a sequence $\left\{\tau_{n}\right\}_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ of stopping times increasing a.s. to infinity as $n \rightarrow+\infty$ such that $\mathbb{E}\left[\left(|\varphi| * \mu\right)_{\tau_{n}}\right]<+\infty$, for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$. For each $n \in \mathbb{N}$, the function $H_{n}: \Omega \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times E \rightarrow\{0,1\}$ defined by $H_{n}:=\mathbf{1}_{\left[0, \tau_{n}\right] \times E}$ is $\widetilde{\mathcal{P}}$-measurable and bounded. Therefore, property (B.1) implies that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[(|\varphi| * \mu)_{\tau_{n}}\right]=M_{\mu}\left[|\varphi| H_{n}\right]=M_{\mu}\left[M_{\mu}[|\varphi| \widetilde{\mathcal{P}}] H_{n}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\left(M_{\mu}[|\varphi| \widetilde{\mathcal{P}}] * \mu\right)_{\tau_{n}}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\left(M_{\mu}[|\varphi| \widetilde{\mathcal{P}}] * \nu\right)_{\tau_{n}}\right]
$$

for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$, where in the last equality we made use of [35, Theorem II.1.8]. This shows that the process $M_{\mu}[|\varphi| \widetilde{\mathcal{P}}] * \nu$ is locally integrable. The converse implication can be shown in the same way. To prove the second part of the lemma, by localization we can assume that $\mathbb{E}\left[\left(|\varphi| * \mu\right)_{\infty}\right]<+\infty$. Let $\tau$ be an arbitrary stopping time. Similarly as above, letting the function $H$ be defined by $H:=\mathbf{1}_{[0, \tau] \times E}$,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[(\varphi * \mu)_{\tau}\right]=M_{\mu}[\varphi H]=M_{\mu}\left[M_{\mu}[\varphi \mid \widetilde{\mathcal{P}}] H\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\left(M_{\mu}[\varphi \mid \widetilde{\mathcal{P}}] * \mu\right)_{\tau}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\left(M_{\mu}[\varphi \mid \widetilde{\mathcal{P}}] * \nu\right)_{\tau}\right]
$$

thus implying that the process $\varphi * \mu-M_{\mu}[\varphi \mid \widetilde{\mathcal{P}}] * \nu$ is a martingale. In view of [35, Theorem I.3.18], this suffices to deduce that $M_{\mu}[\varphi \mid \widetilde{\mathcal{P}}] * \nu$ is the compensator of $\varphi * \mu$.

# Appendix C. Locally Lipschitz and locally bounded functions 

In this appendix, we collect some technical results on locally Lipschitz and locally bounded functions that are used in Section 4. In the following, we denote by $X, Y, Z$ some generic normed spaces. Moreover, we call $(X, m)$ a commutative algebra if $m: X \times X \rightarrow X$ is a continuous symmetric bilinear operator. We denote by $\operatorname{Lip}(X, Y)$ the space of all Lipschitz continuous functions from $X$ to $Y$ and by $\mathrm{B}(X, Y)$ the space of all bounded functions from $X$ to $Y$.

Definition C.1. A function $f: X \rightarrow Y$ is said to be locally Lipschitz if there exists a function $L_{f}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$such that, for every $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$, we have

$$
\left\|f\left(x_{1}\right)-f\left(x_{2}\right)\right\| \leq L_{f}(r)\left\|x_{1}-x_{2}\right\|, \quad \text { for all } x_{1}, x_{2} \in X \text { with }\left\|x_{1}\right\| \vee\left\|x_{2}\right\| \leq r
$$

We denote by $\operatorname{Lip}^{\text {loc }}(X, Y)$ the space of all locally Lipschitz functions $f: X \rightarrow Y$.
We call the function $L_{f}$ appearing in Definition C. 1 a Lipschitz function of $f$. Without loss of generality, we can assume that $L_{f}$ is increasing. If the function $L_{f}$ is bounded, then it can be chosen constant and in this case the function $f$ is Lipschitz continuous.

Definition C.2. A function $f: X \rightarrow Y$ is said to be locally bounded if there exists a function $B_{f}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$such that, for every $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$, we have

$$
\|f(x)\| \leq B_{f}(r), \quad \text { for all } x \in X \text { with }\|x\| \leq r
$$

We denote by $\mathrm{B}^{\text {loc }}(X, Y)$ the space of all locally bounded functions $f: X \rightarrow Y$.
We call the function $B_{f}$ appearing in Definition C. 2 a boundedness function of $f$. Without loss of generality, we can assume that $B_{f}$ is increasing. If the function $B_{f}$ is bounded, then it can be chosen constant and in this case the function $f$ is bounded.

Definition C.3. A function $f: X \rightarrow Y$ is said to satisfy the linear growth condition if there exists a constant $C \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$such that

$$
\|f(x)\| \leq C(1+\|x\|), \quad \text { for all } x \in X
$$

We denote by $\mathrm{LG}(X, Y)$ the space of all functions $f: X \rightarrow Y$ satisfying the linear growth condition.

The following lemma recalls a well-known property of locally Lipschitz functions.
Lemma C.4. It holds that $\operatorname{Lip}^{\mathrm{loc}}(X, Y) \subset \mathrm{B}^{\mathrm{loc}}(X, Y)$.
Lemma C.5. Let $(Y, m)$ be a commutative algebra. Let $f, g \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\mathrm{loc}}(X, Y)$ be arbitrary and denote by $f g=f \cdot g: X \rightarrow Y$ the product $(f g)(x)=m(f(x), g(x))$, for $x \in X$. Then, the following hold:
(1) $f g \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\mathrm{loc}}(X, Y)$;
(2) let $L_{f}, L_{g}, B_{f}, B_{g}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$be Lipschitz and boundedness functions of $f$ and $g$. Then, Lipschitz and boundedness functions of the product fg are given by, for all $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
L_{f g}(r) & =\|m\| \mid\left(L_{f}(r) B_{g}(r)+L_{g}(r) B_{f}(r)\right) \\
B_{f g}(r) & =\|m\| B_{f}(r) B_{g}(r)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. Let $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$be arbitrary. Then, for all $x_{1}, x_{2} \in X$ with $\left\|x_{1}\right\| \vee\left\|x_{2}\right\| \leq r$, we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|f\left(x_{1}\right) g\left(x_{1}\right)-f\left(x_{2}\right) g\left(x_{2}\right)\right\| \leq\left\|f\left(x_{1}\right)\left(g\left(x_{1}\right)-g\left(x_{2}\right)\right)\right\|+\left\|\left(f\left(x_{1}\right)-f\left(x_{2}\right)\right) g\left(x_{2}\right)\right\| \\
& \leq\|m\|\left\|f\left(x_{1}\right)\right\|\left\|g\left(x_{1}\right)-g\left(x_{2}\right)\right\|+\|m\|\left\|f\left(x_{1}\right)-f\left(x_{2}\right)\right\|\left\|g\left(x_{2}\right)\right\| \\
& \leq\|m\|\left(B_{f}(r) L_{g}(r)+L_{f}(r) B_{g}(r)\right)\left\|x_{1}-x_{2}\right\|
\end{aligned}
$$

Furthermore, for all $x \in X$ with $\|x\| \leq r$, we have that

$$
\|f(x) g(x)\| \leq\|m\|\|f(x)\|\|g(x)\| \leq\|m\| B_{f}(r) B_{g}(r)
$$

Lemma C.6. Let $f \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\mathrm{loc}}(X, Y)$ and $g \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\mathrm{loc}}(Y, Z)$ be arbitrary. Then the following hold:
(1) $g \circ f \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\mathrm{loc}}(X, Z)$;
(2) let $L_{f}, L_{g}, B_{f}, B_{g}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$be Lipschitz and boundedness functions of $f$ and $g$. Then, Lipschitz and boundedness functions of the composition $g \circ f$ are given by, for all $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
L_{g \circ f}(r) & =L_{f}(r) L_{g}\left(B_{f}(r)\right) \\
B_{g \circ f}(r) & =B_{g}\left(B_{f}(r)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. Let $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$. For all $x_{1}, x_{2} \in X$ with $\left\|x_{1}\right\| \vee\left\|x_{2}\right\| \leq r$, we have $\left\|f\left(x_{1}\right)\right\| \vee\left\|f\left(x_{2}\right)\right\| \leq B_{f}(r)$. Therefore,

$$
\left\|g\left(f\left(x_{1}\right)\right)-g\left(f\left(x_{2}\right)\right)\right\| \leq L_{g}\left(B_{f}(r)\right)\left\|f\left(x_{1}\right)-f\left(x_{2}\right)\right\| \leq L_{g}\left(B_{f}(r)\right) L_{f}(r)\left\|x_{1}-x_{2}\right\|
$$

Furthermore, for all $x \in X$ with $\|x\| \leq r$, we have $\|f(x)\| \leq B_{f}(r)$ and, hence, $\|g(f(x))\| \leq B_{g}\left(B_{f}(r)\right)$.

\leq & 2 \int_{0}^{\infty}\left|\exp \left(C_{\rho} r\right)(h(x)-g(x))\right|^{2}\left|h^{\prime}(x)\right|^{2} e^{\rho x} \mathrm{~d} x \\
& +2 \int_{0}^{\infty}\left|\left(h^{\prime}(x)-g^{\prime}(x)\right) \exp \left(C_{\rho} r\right)\right|^{2} e^{\rho x} \mathrm{~d} x \\
\leq & 2 \exp \left(C_{\rho} r\right)^{2} C_{\rho}^{2} r^{2}\|h-g\|_{\rho}^{2}+2 \exp \left(C_{\rho} r\right)^{2}\|h-g\|_{\rho}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

and, therefore,

$$
\|\exp (h)-\exp (g)\|_{\rho} \leq \sqrt{2}\left(C_{\rho} r+1\right) \exp \left(C_{\rho} r\right)\|h-g\|_{\rho}
$$

Let $h \in H_{\rho}^{1}$ with $\|h\|_{\rho} \leq r$, for some $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$. By Lemma D. 2 we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\exp (h)\|_{\rho}^{2}= & 1+\int_{0}^{\infty}|\exp (h(x)) h^{\prime}(x)|^{2} e^{\rho x} \mathrm{~d} x \\
\leq & 1+\exp \left(C_{\rho} r\right)^{2} \int_{0}^{\infty}\left|h^{\prime}(x)\right|^{2} e^{\rho x} \mathrm{~d} x \leq 1+r^{2} \exp \left(C_{\rho} r\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

and, hence,

$$
\|\exp (h)\|_{\rho} \leq 1+r \exp \left(C_{\rho} r\right)
$$

Therefore, it follows that

$$
\|1-\lambda \exp (h)\|_{\rho} \leq 1+\lambda\left(1+r \exp \left(C_{\rho} r\right)\right)=1+\lambda+\lambda r \exp \left(C_{\rho} r\right)
$$

For what follows, let $X$ be a normed space.
Proposition D.9. Let $\beta \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\text {loc }}\left(X, H_{\rho}^{0}\right)$ be such that, for some constant $K>0$, we have

$$
\|\beta(h)\|_{\rho} \leq K \sqrt{1+\|h\|_{X}}, \quad \text { for all } h \in X
$$

Then, the product $\alpha:=\mathcal{S} \circ \beta=\beta \cdot \mathcal{I} \beta$ satisfies $\alpha \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\text {loc }}\left(X, H_{\rho}^{0}\right) \cap \operatorname{LG}\left(X, H_{\rho}^{0}\right)$.
Proof. The result follows as a direct consequence of Lemma C. 6 and Lemma D.6.
Let us now introduce the constant

$$
K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}}:=C_{\rho} C_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}}=\left(1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{\rho}}\right) \sqrt{\frac{1}{\rho^{\prime}\left(\rho^{\prime}-\rho\right)}},
$$

where we recall that $C_{\rho}$ and $C_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}}$ are given by (D.1) and (D.2), respectively. For a constant $K>0$, we introduce the strictly increasing function

$$
V_{K}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}, \quad V_{K}(r):=r(1+r) \exp (K r)
$$

and we denote by $W_{K}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$its inverse. We also introduce the strictly increasing function

$$
w_{K}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}, \quad w_{K}(r):=W_{K}(r) \wedge r
$$

Proposition D.10. Let $\gamma \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\text {loc }}\left(X, H_{\rho^{\prime}}^{0}\right)$ and $\lambda>0$. We define the product

$$
\alpha_{\lambda}:=\gamma(1-\lambda \exp (-\mathcal{I} \gamma))
$$

Then, the following hold:
(1) $\alpha_{\lambda} \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\text {loc }}\left(X, H_{\rho}^{0}\right)$;
(2) there exists a constant $K>0$ such that Lipschitz and boundedness functions of $\alpha_{\lambda}$ are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& L_{\alpha_{\lambda}}(r)=K L_{\gamma}(r)\left((1+\lambda)+\lambda V_{K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}}}\left(B_{\gamma}(r)\right)\right) \\
& B_{\alpha_{\lambda}}(r)=K\left(B_{\gamma}(r)+\lambda V_{K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}}}\left(B_{\gamma}(r)\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$, where $L_{\gamma}$ and $B_{\gamma}$ are any Lipschitz and boundedness functions of $\gamma$.

Proof. By Lemma D. 5 we have that $\mathcal{I} \in \operatorname{Lip}\left(H_{\rho^{\prime}}^{0}, H_{\rho}^{1}\right)$, a Lipschitz constant is given by $L_{\mathcal{I}}=C_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}}$ and a boundedness function is given by $B_{\mathcal{I}}(r)=C_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}} r$, for all $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$. Let us define $\Gamma:=-\mathcal{I} \circ \gamma$. By Lemma C.6, we have that $\Gamma \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\text {loc }}\left(X, H_{\rho}^{1}\right)$ and Lipschitz and boundedness functions are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& L_{\Gamma}(r)=L_{\gamma}(r) L_{\mathcal{I}}=C_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}} L_{\gamma}(r) \\
& B_{\Gamma}(r)=B_{\mathcal{I}}\left(B_{\gamma}(r)\right)=C_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}} B_{\gamma}(r)
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$. Let us then define $e_{\lambda}: H_{\rho}^{1} \rightarrow H_{\rho}$ by

$$
e_{\lambda}(h):=1-\lambda \exp (h), \quad \text { for all } h \in H_{\rho}^{1}
$$

By Lemma D.8, it holds that $e_{\lambda} \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\text {loc }}\left(H_{\rho}^{1}, H_{\rho}\right)$ and there exists a constant $K_{1}>0$, not depending on $\lambda$, such that Lipschitz and boundedness functions of $e_{\lambda}$ are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& L_{e_{\lambda}}(r)=K_{1} \lambda(1+r) \exp \left(C_{\rho} r\right) \\
& B_{e_{\lambda}}(r)=1+\lambda+\lambda r \exp \left(C_{\rho} r\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By Lemma C.6, we have $e_{\lambda} \circ \Gamma \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\text {loc }}\left(X, H_{\rho}\right)$ and Lipschitz and boundedness functions are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
L_{e_{\lambda} \circ \Gamma}(r) & =L_{\Gamma}(r) L_{e_{\lambda}}\left(B_{\Gamma}(r)\right)=K_{1} C_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}} L_{\gamma}(r) \lambda\left(1+B_{\Gamma}(r)\right) \exp \left(C_{\rho} B_{\Gamma}(r)\right) \\
& =K_{1} C_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}} L_{\gamma}(r) \lambda\left(1+C_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}} B_{\gamma}(r)\right) \exp \left(K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}} B_{\gamma}(r)\right) \\
B_{e_{\lambda} \circ \Gamma}(r) & =B_{e_{\lambda}}\left(B_{\Gamma}(r)\right)=1+\lambda+\lambda B_{\Gamma}(r) \exp \left(C_{\rho} B_{\Gamma}(r)\right) \\
& =1+\lambda+\lambda C_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}} B_{\gamma}(r) \exp \left(K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}} B_{\gamma}(r)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$. Therefore, there exists a constant $K_{2}>0$, only depending on $\rho$ and $\rho^{\prime}$, such that Lipschitz and boundedness functions of $e_{\lambda} \circ \Gamma$ are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& L_{e_{\lambda} \circ \Gamma}(r)=K_{2} \lambda L_{\gamma}(r)\left(1+B_{\gamma}(r)\right) \exp \left(K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}} B_{\gamma}(r)\right) \\
& B_{e_{\lambda} \circ \Gamma}(r)=K_{2}\left(1+\lambda+\lambda B_{\gamma}(r) \exp \left(K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}} B_{\gamma}(r)\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining Lemma C. 5 and Lemmata D.3, D.4, it follows that $\alpha_{\lambda}=\gamma \cdot\left(e_{\lambda} \circ \Gamma\right) \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\text {loc }}\left(X, H_{\rho}^{0}\right)$ and that Lipschitz and boundedness functions are given by, for all $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
L_{\alpha_{\lambda}}(r)= & \left\|m \|\left(L_{\gamma}(r) B_{e_{\lambda} \circ \Gamma}(r)+B_{\gamma}(r) L_{e_{\lambda} \circ \Gamma}(r)\right)\right. \\
= & \left\|m \|\left(L_{\gamma}(r) K_{2}\left(1+\lambda+\lambda B_{\gamma}(r) \exp \left(K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}} B_{\gamma}(r)\right)\right)\right.\right. \\
& \left.\left.+B_{\gamma}(r) K_{2} \lambda L_{\gamma}(r)\left(1+B_{\gamma}(r)\right) \exp \left(K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}} B_{\gamma}(r)\right)\right)\right) \\
= & \left\|m \|^{L_{\gamma}(r) K_{2}\left((1+\lambda)+\left(\lambda B_{\gamma}(r)+\lambda B_{\gamma}(r)\left(1+B_{\gamma}(r)\right)\right) \exp \left(K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}} B_{\gamma}(r)\right)\right)\right. \\
\leq & \left\|m \|^{L_{\gamma}(r) K_{2}\left((1+\lambda)+2 \lambda V_{K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}}}\left(B_{\gamma}(r)\right)\right)\right. \\
B_{\alpha_{\lambda}}(r) & =\|m\| B_{\gamma}(r) B_{e_{\lambda} \circ \Gamma}(r) \\
& =\left\|m \|^{B_{\gamma}(r) K_{2}\left(1+\lambda+\lambda B_{\gamma}(r) \exp \left(K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}} B_{\gamma}(r)\right)\right)}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Proposition D.11. Let $(E, \mathcal{E}, F)$ be a measure space and $(Z, \mathcal{Z})$ a measurable space. Let $\gamma: X \times E \rightarrow$ $H_{\rho^{\prime}}^{0}$ be a $\mathcal{B}(X) \otimes \mathcal{E}$-measurable function and $\lambda: Z \times E \rightarrow(0, \infty)$ a $\mathcal{Z} \otimes \mathcal{E}$-measurable function. Suppose that there exist a nonnegative function $\kappa \in L^{1}(F) \cap L^{2}(F) \cap L^{3}(F)$, an increasing function $M: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$and a function $\Lambda: Z \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$such that the following conditions are satisfied:
(1) $\gamma(\cdot, x) \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\text {loc }}\left(X, H_{\rho^{\prime}}^{0}\right)$, for every $x \in E$;
(2) for every $x \in E$, there exists a Lipschitz function $L_{\gamma(\cdot, x)}$ of $\gamma(\cdot, x)$ such that

$$
L_{\gamma(\cdot, x)}(r) \leq \kappa(x) M(r), \quad \text { for all } r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}
$$

(3) for every $x \in E$, there exists a boundedness function $B_{\gamma(\cdot, x)}$ of $\gamma(\cdot, x)$ such that

$$
B_{\gamma(\cdot, x)}(r) \leq w_{K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}}}(\kappa(x)(1+r)), \quad \text { for all } r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}
$$

(4) it holds that

$$
|\lambda(z, x)| \leq \Lambda(z) \kappa(x), \quad \text { for all } z \in Z \text { and } x \in E
$$

Then, the following hold:
(1) the Bochner integrals

$$
\alpha(z, h):=\int_{E} \gamma(h, x) \cdot(1-\lambda(z, x) \exp (-\mathcal{I} \gamma(h, x))) F(\mathrm{~d} x), \quad \text { for }(z, h) \in Z \times X
$$

provide a well-defined $\mathcal{Z} \otimes \mathcal{B}(X)$-measurable function $\alpha: Z \times X \rightarrow H_{\rho}^{0}$;
(2) there exists an increasing function $L_{1}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$such that, for all $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$and $h, g \in X$ with $\|h\|_{X} \vee\|g\|_{X} \leq r$, it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{E}\|\gamma(h, x)-\gamma(g, x)\|_{\rho}^{2} F(\mathrm{~d} x) & \leq L_{1}(r)\|h-g\|_{X}^{2} \\
\|\alpha(z, h)-\alpha(z, g)\|_{\rho} & \leq L_{1}(r)(1+\Lambda(z))\|h-g\|_{X}, \quad \text { for all } z \in Z
\end{aligned}
$$

(3) there exists a constant $L_{2} \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$such that, for all $h, g \in X$, it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{E}\|\gamma(h, x)\|_{\rho}^{2} F(\mathrm{~d} x) & \leq L_{2}\left(1+\|h\|_{X}^{2}\right) \\
\|\alpha(z, h)\|_{\rho} & \leq L_{2}(1+\Lambda(z))(1+\|h\|_{X}), \quad \text { for all } z \in Z
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. Let $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$. By Lemma D. 4 and (D.3), for all $h, g \in X$ with $\|h\|_{X} \vee\|g\|_{X} \leq r$, it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{E}\|\gamma(h, x)-\gamma(g, x)\|_{\rho}^{2} F(\mathrm{~d} x) & \leq\left(\int_{E} L_{\gamma(\cdot, x)}(r)^{2} F(\mathrm{~d} x)\right)\|h-g\|_{X}^{2} \\
& \leq M(r)^{2}\left(\int_{E} \kappa(x)^{2} F(\mathrm{~d} x)\right)\|h-g\|_{X}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

thus showing (D.7). Let $h \in X$ be arbitrary and set $r:=\|h\|_{X}$. Using Lemma D.4, estimate (D.4) and the inequality $w_{K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}}}(r) \leq r$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{E}\|\gamma(h, x)\|_{\rho}^{2} F(\mathrm{~d} x) & \leq \int_{E} B_{\gamma(\cdot, x)}(r)^{2} F(\mathrm{~d} x) \leq \int_{E} w_{K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}}}(\kappa(x)(1+r))^{2} F(\mathrm{~d} x) \\
& \leq(1+r)^{2} \int_{E} \kappa(x)^{2} F(\mathrm{~d} x) \leq 2 \int_{E} \kappa(x)^{2} F(\mathrm{~d} x)\left(1+\|h\|_{X}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which proves (D.9). In view of Proposition D.10, we can define the mapping $\bar{\alpha}: Z \times X \times E \rightarrow H_{\rho}^{0}$ by

$$
\bar{\alpha}(z, h, x):=\gamma(h, x) \cdot(1-\lambda(z, x) \exp (-\mathcal{I} \gamma(h, x))), \quad(z, h, x) \in Z \times X \times E
$$

Note that $\bar{\alpha}$ is $\mathcal{Z} \otimes \mathcal{B}(X) \otimes \mathcal{E}$-measurable, because $\gamma$ is $\mathcal{B}(X) \otimes \mathcal{E}$-measurable and $\lambda$ is $\mathcal{Z} \otimes \mathcal{E}$-measurable. Let $z \in Z$ and $x \in E$ be arbitrary. Taking into account (D.5), Proposition D. 10 implies that $\bar{\alpha}(z, \cdot, x) \in$ $\operatorname{Lip}^{\text {loc }}\left(X, H_{\rho^{\prime}}^{0}\right)$ and there exists a constant $K>0$ such that Lipschitz and boundedness functions of $\bar{\alpha}(z, \cdot, x)$ are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& L_{\bar{\alpha}(z, \cdot, x)}(r)=K L_{\gamma(\cdot, x)}(r)(1+\Lambda(z) \kappa(x)+\Lambda(z) \kappa(x) V_{K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}}}\left(B_{\gamma(\cdot, x)}(r)\right)), \\
& B_{\bar{\alpha}(z, \cdot, x)}(r)=K\left(B_{\gamma(\cdot, x)}(r)+\Lambda(z) \kappa(x) V_{K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}}}\left(B_{\gamma(\cdot, x)}(r)\right)\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$. By (D.3), (D.4) and the inequalities $V_{K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}}}\left(w_{K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}}}(r)\right) \leq r$ and $w_{K_{\rho, \rho^{\prime}}}(r) \leq r$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& L_{\bar{\alpha}(z, \cdot, x)}(r) \leq K \kappa(x) M(r)\left(1+\Lambda(z) \kappa(x)+\Lambda(z) \kappa(x)^{2}(1+r)\right) \\
& B_{\bar{\alpha}(z, \cdot, x)}(r) \leq K\left(\kappa(x)(1+r)+\Lambda(z) \kappa(x)^{2}(1+r)\right)=K\left(\kappa(x)+\Lambda(z) \kappa(x)^{2}\right)(1+r)
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$. The Bochner integrals (D.6) are given by

$$
\alpha(z, h)=\int_{E} \bar{\alpha}(z, h, x) F(\mathrm{~d} x), \quad \text { for all }(z, h) \in Z \times X
$$

Therefore, by Lemma C. 7 the Bochner integrals (D.6) provide a well-defined function $\alpha: Z \times X \rightarrow H_{\rho^{\prime}}^{0}$ and $\alpha(z, \cdot) \in \operatorname{Lip}^{\text {loc }}\left(X, H_{\rho^{\prime}}^{0}\right)$, for every $z \in Z$. Furthermore, the mapping $\alpha$ is $\mathcal{Z} \otimes \mathcal{B}(X)$-measurable, because $\bar{\alpha}$ is $\mathcal{Z} \otimes \mathcal{B}(X) \otimes \mathcal{E}$-measurable. Moreover, by Lemma C.7, for all $z \in Z, r \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$and $h, g \in X$ with $\|h\|_{X} \vee\|g\|_{X} \leq r$, it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \|\alpha(z, h)-\alpha(z, g)\|_{\rho} \leq\left(\int_{E} L_{\bar{\alpha}(z, \cdot, x)}(r) F(\mathrm{~d} x)\right)\|h-g\|_{X} \\
& \leq K M(r)\left(\int_{E} \kappa(x) F(\mathrm{~d} x)+\Lambda(z) \int_{E} \kappa(x)^{2} F(\mathrm{~d} x)+\Lambda(z)(1+r) \int_{E} \kappa(x)^{3} F(\mathrm{~d} x)\right)\|h-g\|_{X}
\end{aligned}
$$

thus proving (D.8). Finally, let $z \in Z$ and $h \in X$ and set $r:=\|h\|_{X}$. Then, (D.10) follows by noting that, as a consequence of Lemma C.7, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\alpha(z, h)\|_{\rho} & \leq\left(\int_{E} B_{\bar{\alpha}(z, \cdot, x)}(r) F(\mathrm{~d} x)\right) \\
& \leq K\left(\int_{E} \kappa(x) F(\mathrm{~d} x)+\Lambda(z) \int_{E} \kappa(x)^{2} F(\mathrm{~d} x)\right)\left(1+\|h\|_{X}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

abstract:
We develop a unified framework for modeling multiple term structures arising
in financial, insurance, and energy markets, adopting an extended
Heath-Jarrow-Morton (HJM) approach under the real-world probability. We study
market viability and characterize the set of local martingale deflators. We
conduct an analysis of the associated stochastic partial differential equation
(SPDE), addressing existence and uniqueness of solutions, invariance properties
and existence of affine realizations.
